description.narrative: Desarrollo de Enfoques de Manejo de Paisajes en el Sistema Nacional de Áreas Protegidas del Ecuador para mejorar la Conservación de la Vida Silvestre en Peligro de Extinción Mundial
capital of a political entity
Ecuadors PA system applies landscape approaches to increase its effectiveness for conservation of globally important wildlife

Replication
O6 Increases in number of PAs and adjacent landscapes nationwide with planning and management instruments incorporating project models and lessons learnt project
see notes in Table 19

comment.narrative: 0 no models or lessons learnt have been generated

2 PAs and 2 Provincial GADs other than those directly targeted by the project have planning and management instruments which incorporate the models and lessons learnt which are generated through the project

During the reporting period the project has coordinated actions for the development of local planning instruments and support the declaration of new protected areas 21000 ha with the Decentralized Autonomous Governments GADs in the provinces of Imbabura and Carchi and the strengthening capacity for the personal at the protected areas for which the project developed a protocol for the Biological Monitoring of Wildlife to this end the administration of the Yasuni and Antinsana National Parks have decided to adopt and implement this model for monitoring their areas of work which contribute to the management of wildlife criteria that form part of systematization processes automation and repeatability at institutional level since in the future they will seek to have these efforts indexed in scientific journals
Regarding the relationship with provincial GADs the consultancy Assessment of the Tenure of the Conservation Area Cordillera Oriental and its Roadmap in the Province of Carchi now comes into effect providing input for SNAP record entry and its future declaration as a protected area

2 PAs and 2 Provincial GADs other than those directly targeted by the project have planning and management instruments which incorporate the models and lessons learnt which are generated through the project

During the reporting period the project has coordinated actions for the development of local planning instruments and support the declaration of new protected areas 21000 ha with the Decentralized Autonomous Governments GADs in the provinces of Imbabura and Carchi and the strengthening capacity for the personal at the protected areas for which the project developed a protocol for the Biological Monitoring of Wildlife to this end the administration of the Yasuni and Antinsana National Parks have decided to adopt and implement this model for monitoring their areas of work which contribute to the management of wildlife criteria that form part of systematization processes automation and repeatability at institutional level since in the future they will seek to have these efforts indexed in scientific journals
Regarding the relationship with provincial GADs the consultancy Assessment of the Tenure of the Conservation Area Cordillera Oriental and its Roadmap in the Province of Carchi now comes into effect providing input for SNAP record entry and its future declaration as a protected area

description.narrative:
Status of target species
O1 Maintenance or increases in abundance of target species in target landscapes
See Table 18 for species by landscape

comment.narrative:
IUCN Red List status gives some indication of threat status
See Table 18 for IUCN categories by species

In all target PAs corridors and buffer zones
0 negative change in abundance of species with low reproductive rates
10 increase in abundance of those with high reproductive rates
See Table 10 for landscapes and targets per species

The projects implementation of the program of biological monitoring at landscape scale has begun starting with field sampling to obtain baseline information on the five selected landscapes sites 1 The Pambilar Wildlife Refuge Cotacachi Cayapas low zone 2 Cotacachi Cayapas Ecological Reserve high zone El Angel Ecological Reserve 3 Cofán Bermejo Ecological Reserve Llanganates National Park 4 Cuyabeno Corridor Yasuní and 5 Podocarpus National Park For this fieldwork the document Protocol for Recording and Monitoring Presence of Populations of Priority Species through a Landscape Approach in Selected Areas had previously been developed
To implement this monitoring a group of ten Social Environmental Technicians from the United Nations Volunteers Program was selected hired trained and equipped 200 camera traps were acquired along with other basic equipment for field sampling in which the active participation of staff of rangers and technicians working in the seven protected areas covered by the project was given
Additionally the process was started by developing a comprehensive financial sustainability strategy for the management of wildlife in the project area which includes strengthening the management committees of PAs as well as plans for community wildlife management and the expansion of protected areas within the country
To fulfill this indicator several communication elements and awareness to the community governance wildlife management were considered to be included

In all target PAs corridors and buffer zones
0 negative change in abundance of species with low reproductive rates
10 increase in abundance of those with high reproductive rates
See Table 10 for landscapes and targets per species

The projects implementation of the program of biological monitoring at landscape scale has begun starting with field sampling to obtain baseline information on the five selected landscapes sites 1 The Pambilar Wildlife Refuge Cotacachi Cayapas low zone 2 Cotacachi Cayapas Ecological Reserve high zone El Angel Ecological Reserve 3 Cofán Bermejo Ecological Reserve Llanganates National Park 4 Cuyabeno Corridor Yasuní and 5 Podocarpus National Park For this fieldwork the document Protocol for Recording and Monitoring Presence of Populations of Priority Species through a Landscape Approach in Selected Areas had previously been developed
To implement this monitoring a group of ten Social Environmental Technicians from the United Nations Volunteers Program was selected hired trained and equipped 200 camera traps were acquired along with other basic equipment for field sampling in which the active participation of staff of rangers and technicians working in the seven protected areas covered by the project was given
Additionally the process was started by developing a comprehensive financial sustainability strategy for the management of wildlife in the project area which includes strengthening the management committees of PAs as well as plans for community wildlife management and the expansion of protected areas within the country
To fulfill this indicator several communication elements and awareness to the community governance wildlife management were considered to be included

description.narrative:
Threat Reduction
O3 Reductions in levels of illegal bushmeat trade in three target landscapes 1 3 4 covering 5289900ha

comment.narrative:
In 2011 ̴ 19 tyr of bushmeat were traded in Pompeya market obtained from Yasuni NP in San Pedro market Yasuni Biosphere Reserve 15tyear sold over 2 sample years and in Coca market Puerto Francisco de Orellana 17tyear over 4 sample years
See Table 19

Quantities of bushmeat sold in markets in 3 target landscapes 1 3 and 4 are reduced by 30 over the project period
See Table 19 for explanation

The records on the retention of bush meat for 2014 were systematized and analyzed and these were reported to the Wildlife Unit of DNB from which technical and administrative recommendations were issued so as to improve the registration process
Information was collected relating to the National System of Honorary Wildlife Inspectors whose members contribute to the prevention of wildlife trafficking including bush meat Relevant information will be developed and used for the implementation of proposals for management and sustainability in protected areas during subsequent periods

Quantities of bushmeat sold in markets in 3 target landscapes 1 3 and 4 are reduced by 30 over the project period
See Table 19 for explanation

Information was collected relating to the National System of Honorary Wildlife Inspectors whose members contribute to the prevention of wildlife trafficking including bush meat Relevant information will be developed and used for the implementation of proposals for management and sustainability in protected areas during subsequent periods

description.narrative:
Status of target habitat
O2 Increases in coverage of vegetation in corridorsbuffer zones of all 5 target landscapes of value for habitat and connectivity for target wildlife species

comment.narrative:
In December 2012 3659252ha of forests and other areas of native vegetation were under protection through Socio Bosque 331565ha as Forest Heritage Protection Forests or as part of the subsystem of private provincial or community reserves in project landscapes
See Table 19 for areas by landscape

An additional 300000ha of forest native vegetation included in Socio Bosque programme in 2 target landscapes and managed in accordance with project guidelines in support of wildlife conservation
2 municipal PAs gazette landscapes 1 3 combined area of 50000ha
Other areas remain stable

By means of Ministerial Agreement No 011 of February 26 2014 The Ministry of Environment MAE declared a new protected area in the Colonso Chalupas Biological Reserve which covers an area of 93246 hectares and is located in the Napo Province between the Antisana Ecological Reserve and Llanganates National Park contributing directly to connectivity in the landscape project 3 Cofan Bermejo Llanganates
The project provided support to the Decentralized Autonomous Governments GADs in the provinces of Carchi and Imbabura in the process of declaring protected areas PAs for the GADs subsystem part of the National System of Protected Areas in Ecuador SNAP In the case of the Province of Carchi this process included the municipalities of Tulcán Huaca Montufar and Bolivar In this province 16000 hectares in the Eastern Cordillera will be used as a conservation area through ordinance of Carchi Provincial GAD In the case of the Province of Imbabura the Municipality of Pimampiro was included in the process of becoming a Protected Area which is within its remit
The project is providing support and technical advice to the Decentralized Autonomous Municipal Government of Francisco de Orellana El Coca in the process of declaring a protected forest of 200 hectares located to the south of the city in the CocaZoo municipal zoo zone of influence The project will directly support the gathering of information about wildlife which will be used as input in the process of declaring the protected area

An additional 300000ha of forest native vegetation included in Socio Bosque programme in 2 target landscapes and managed in accordance with project guidelines in support of wildlife conservation
2 municipal PAs gazette landscapes 1 3 combined area of 50000ha
Other areas remain stable

By means of Ministerial Agreement No 011 of February 26 2014 The Ministry of Environment MAE declared a new protected area in the Colonso Chalupas Biological Reserve which covers an area of 93246 hectares and is located in the Napo Province between the Antisana Ecological Reserve and Llanganates National Park contributing directly to connectivity in the landscape project 3 Cofan Bermejo Llanganates
The project provided support to the Decentralized Autonomous Governments GADs in the provinces of Carchi and Imbabura in the process of declaring protected areas PAs for the GADs subsystem part of the National System of Protected Areas in Ecuador SNAP In the case of the Province of Carchi this process included the municipalities of Tulcán Huaca Montufar and Bolivar In this province 16000 hectares in the Eastern Cordillera will be used as a conservation area through ordinance of Carchi Provincial GAD In the case of the Province of Imbabura the Municipality of Pimampiro was included in the process of becoming a Protected Area which is within its remit
The project is providing support and technical advice to the Decentralized Autonomous Municipal Government of Francisco de Orellana El Coca in the process of declaring a protected forest of 200 hectares located to the south of the city in the CocaZoo municipal zoo zone of influence The project will directly support the gathering of information about wildlife which will be used as input in the process of declaring the protected area

description.narrative:
Enabling environment
O4 Increases in levels and sustainability of financial resources in support of the sustainable management of wildlife

comment.narrative:
SNAP financial gap in 2011 was 2469806 basic scenario and 4602300 optimal scenario with no budget specifically earmarked for wildlife conservation and management
None of the 12 Decentralised Governments GADs covering the Project landscapes have specific budgetary provisions in support of the conservation and management of threatened wildlife

MAE covering salary costs of the 10 wildlife technicians in 5 target landscapes 75684year total
SNAP budget has specific earmarking for wildlife conservation
5 GADs have allocated budget to replicate livelihood production activities in additional communities in target landscapes with the aim of reducing pressures on wildlife
12 GADs in Project landscapes have specific budgetary provisions for wildlife conservation management

MAE is covering the salaries of five technical specialists in the wildlife area three biologists and two veterinarians thus supporting the management of the project throughout 2014The corresponding national contribution was 33123228 and will be 15006854 in 2015 which shows a considerable annual increase in national spending on the projects implementation
A representative of the Executive Directorate of the Consortium of Autonomous Provincial Governments of Ecuador CONGOPE forms part of the Landscapes Wildlife Project Committee
The GAD of the Province of Imbabura has assigned an amount of approximately 50000 to activities related to the management of wildlife in the province in 2015
The document for the prioritization of the project was prepared and presented by the National Secretariat of Planning and Development SENPLADES which will have fiscal resources until completion

MAE covering salary costs of the 10 wildlife technicians in 5 target landscapes 75684year total
SNAP budget has specific earmarking for wildlife conservation
5 GADs have allocated budget to replicate livelihood production activities in additional communities in target landscapes with the aim of reducing pressures on wildlife
12 GADs in Project landscapes have specific budgetary provisions for wildlife conservation management

MAE is covering the salaries of five technical specialists in the wildlife area three biologists and two veterinarians thus supporting the management of the project throughout 2014The corresponding national contribution was 33123228 and will be 15006854 in 2015 which shows a considerable annual increase in national spending on the projects implementation
A representative of the Executive Directorate of the Consortium of Autonomous Provincial Governments of Ecuador CONGOPE forms part of the Landscapes Wildlife Project Committee
The GAD of the Province of Imbabura has assigned an amount of approximately 50000 to activities related to the management of wildlife in the province in 2015
The document for the prioritization of the project was prepared and presented by the National Secretariat of Planning and Development SENPLADES which will have fiscal resources until completion

description.narrative:
Enabling environment
O5 Existence and application of normative instruments regarding conservation and management of wildlife

comment.narrative: TULAS is under reform regarding normative framework for conservation and management of wildlife
The respective normative framework in TULAS includes illegal trafficking commercial hunting sport hunting norms and is under application nationwide

The project contributes to the reform Unified Text of Secondary Legislation from the Ministry of Environment TULSMA for its acronym in Spanish previously called TULAS and documents of the Organic Environmental Code COA with respect to issues of conservation and management of wildlife including the issues of trafficking and commercial hunting carried out These instruments are currently in a phase prior to publication and entry into effect
Along with the DNB Wildlife Unit this project made contributions to combat issues in the illegal trade of wildlife and commercial hunting through the law called the Organic Criminal Code COIP which has already been in effect since August 2014 and which in Article 247 expressly defines crimes against wild flora and fauna
To this end the Official Gazette No 385 Ministerial Decree No 261 published in November 2014 prohibits hunting in the country considering it an illegal activity except for subsistence whose rules are currently in development Current regulation do not codify on sports hunting
The respective normative framework in TULAS includes illegal trafficking commercial hunting sport hunting norms and is under application nationwide

The project contributes to the reform Unified Text of Secondary Legislation from the Ministry of Environment TULSMA for its acronym in Spanish previously called TULAS and documents of the Organic Environmental Code COA with respect to issues of conservation and management of wildlife including the issues of trafficking and commercial hunting carried out These instruments are currently in a phase prior to publication and entry into effect
Along with the DNB Wildlife Unit this project made contributions to combat issues in the illegal trade of wildlife and commercial hunting through the law called the Organic Criminal Code COIP which has already been in effect since August 2014 and which in Article 247 expressly defines crimes against wild flora and fauna
To this end the Official Gazette No 385 Ministerial Decree No 261 published in November 2014 prohibits hunting in the country considering it an illegal activity except for subsistence whose rules are currently in development Current regulation do not codify on sports hunting

description.narrative: Management of nonPA areas in 5 target landscapes contributes effectively to the conservation of threatened wildlife

21 Increases in of Descentralised Governments GAD in target landscapes with planning regulatory and normative instruments and associated budgetary provisions that incorporate specific provisions for reducing pressures on threatened wildlife

comment.narrative:
012 target landscape GADS have Territorial Land Use Plans TLUP that incorporate specific provisions for reducing pressures on wildlife
TLUP of Orellana Municipality includes specific objectives related to wildlife conservation
0 provincial GADs in project landscapes have or apply regulatory or normative instruments in relation to illegal hunting and trafficking of wildlife

512 GADs in target landscape with TLUP that incorporate specific provisions for reducing pressures on wildlife and 5 1 per landscape apply ordinances which regulate and sanction illegal hunting and trafficking of wildlife harmonized with the national norm with associated budgetary provisions

The project contributed to the review comments and technical suggestions on incorporating specific measures to reduce pressure on wildlife in the document Guidelines for Preparation of Development Plans and Zoning of the Autonomous Governments prepared by the National Secretariat of Planning and Development SENPLADES The suggestions given were accepted and incorporated into the final document
An interinstitutional cooperation agreement was signed between the Ministry of Environment and the Municipal GAD of Orellana so as to establish mutual commitments for the management of wildlife The support is part of the project by providing technical advice and veterinarian inputs to animals kept in the zoo of Orellana at the same time they offer us a physical space and basic services to provide a service to animals In addition it is proposed to make joint campaigns of sterilization of domestic animals which affects wildlife found around the area
In meetings held with the representative of CONGOPE activities were planned to improve the capabilities of the technical environmental management of various provincial GADs These meetings include a focus on specific criteria for the proper management of wildlife
Through analysis of the Socio Economic diagnosis information on the current state of the regulatory function of the GADs as well as their policy instruments is being organized in order to reduce pressure on wildlife
Hiring a specialist for the relationship with GADs will also strengthen activities in this area

512 GADs in target landscape with TLUP that incorporate specific provisions for reducing pressures on wildlife and 5 1 per landscape apply ordinances which regulate and sanction illegal hunting and trafficking of wildlife harmonized with the national norm with associated budgetary provisions

The project contributed to the review comments and technical suggestions on incorporating specific measures to reduce pressure on wildlife in the document Guidelines for Preparation of Development Plans and Zoning of the Autonomous Governments prepared by the National Secretariat of Planning and Development SENPLADES The suggestions given were accepted and incorporated into the final document
An interinstitutional cooperation agreement was signed between the Ministry of Environment and the Municipal GAD of Orellana so as to establish mutual commitments for the management of wildlife The support is part of the project by providing technical advice and veterinarian inputs to animals kept in the zoo of Orellana at the same time they offer us a physical space and basic services to provide a service to animals In addition it is proposed to make joint campaigns of sterilization of domestic animals which affects wildlife found around the area
In meetings held with the representative of CONGOPE activities were planned to improve the capabilities of the technical environmental management of various provincial GADs These meetings include a focus on specific criteria for the proper management of wildlife
Through analysis of the Socio Economic diagnosis information on the current state of the regulatory function of the GADs as well as their policy instruments is being organized in order to reduce pressure on wildlife
Hiring a specialist for the relationship with GADs will also strengthen activities in this area

description.narrative: 25 Reductions in frequency of conflicts between fauna and agricultural andor ranching activities in all 5 target landscapes

comment.narrative:
Numbers of cases in which wild fauna was reported to have attacked cattle
Andean bears 21 in Carchi 2009 2013 1 in Tungurahua 2013 45 in Imbabura 20112013
Jaguars 6 in Morono Santiago 2013 1 in Imbabura 20112013
50 reduction in frequency of reported attacks by wild fauna on cattle due to awareness raising and the introduction of improved management practices for agriculture and ranching

The project organized the 1st National Symposium on People Fauna Conflict Management and Wildlife Trafficking which aimed to create opportunities to exchange experiences awareness and knowledge related to these issues and jointly find ways to manage these problems more effectively
The project run in conjunction with the Wildlife DNB Unit proposed that livestock deaths caused by attacks from wild animals will be covered by an Agricultural Insurance Agroseguros provided by the Ministry of Agriculture Livestock Aquaculture and Fisheries MAGAP This proposal was discussed and finally accepted for implementation In its initial phase only cattle are included
10 people fauna conflict maps of vulnerability were developed and validated in five landscape sites
50 reduction in frequency of reported attacks by wild fauna on cattle due to awareness raising and the introduction of improved management practices for agriculture and ranching

The project organized the 1st National Symposium on People Fauna Conflict Management and Wildlife Trafficking which aimed to create opportunities to exchange experiences awareness and knowledge related to these issues and jointly find ways to manage these problems more effectively
The project run in conjunction with the Wildlife DNB Unit proposed that livestock deaths caused by attacks from wild animals will be covered by an Agricultural Insurance Agroseguros provided by the Ministry of Agriculture Livestock Aquaculture and Fisheries MAGAP This proposal was discussed and finally accepted for implementation In its initial phase only cattle are included
10 people fauna conflict maps of vulnerability were developed and validated in five landscape sites

description.narrative: 23 Reduction in detected incidence of wildlife and bushmeat trade per unit of effort at pilot enforcement points

comment.narrative: To be determined when enforcement points are set up
50 reduction in detectionunit effort due to the deterrent effect of the enforcement points

Technicians systematize project data and periodically analyze records of wildlife retention including bushmeat which are reported to the Wildlife DNB Unit enabling information to be monitored and trends to be detected
The project provided technical support to the Forestry and Wildlife Stations regarding the retention of bushmeat and wildlife in Santa Cecilia Sucumbios Province Baeza Napo Province El Coca Orellana Province and Mera Pastaza Province
The project contributed to the purchase of equipment required for the transportation and proper management of confiscated wildlife as a result of checks on illegal trafficking Delivery is made to several of MAEs provincial departments The team of biologists and veterinarians and the Wildlife DNB Project Unit also have access to this equipment
50 reduction in detectionunit effort due to the deterrent effect of the enforcement points

Technicians systematize project data and periodically analyze records of wildlife retention including bushmeat which are reported to the Wildlife DNB Unit enabling information to be monitored and trends to be detected
The project provided technical support to the Forestry and Wildlife Stations regarding the retention of bushmeat and wildlife in Santa Cecilia Sucumbios Province Baeza Napo Province El Coca Orellana Province and Mera Pastaza Province
The project contributed to the purchase of equipment required for the transportation and proper management of confiscated wildlife as a result of checks on illegal trafficking Delivery is made to several of MAEs provincial departments The team of biologists and veterinarians and the Wildlife DNB Project Unit also have access to this equipment

description.narrative: 22 Increase in the percentage of detected illegal actions transporting wildlife and bushmeat or selling bushmeat in markets in pilot landscapes that are successfully sanctioned

comment.narrative: To be established by midterm once the norms and fines are re or defined Currently no specific controlinspection points to detect infringements no detailed sanctions defined for wildlife offences and the fines used are not appropriate
50 increase on baseline of successful sanctions

The project team developed the database relating to administrative and criminal procedures related to crimes against wildlife at a national level initiated by MAE in 2014 allowing to identify critical points technical and legal barriers in administrative and criminal proceedings carried out by the Ministry of Environment this information will be entered into the Information System Biodiversity SIB
The new Criminal Code COIP which came into effect in August 2014 explicitly defines crimes against wildlife and establishes a clear penalty system
Following MAEs environmental policies a Wildlife DNB Unit prepared a Proposal for the Regulation of Hunting and Local Wildlife Operations in Ecuador which will also be included in the reform proposal of TULSMA
50 increase on baseline of successful sanctions

The project team developed the database relating to administrative and criminal procedures related to crimes against wildlife at a national level initiated by MAE in 2014 allowing to identify critical points technical and legal barriers in administrative and criminal proceedings carried out by the Ministry of Environment this information will be entered into the Information System Biodiversity SIB
The new Criminal Code COIP which came into effect in August 2014 explicitly defines crimes against wildlife and establishes a clear penalty system
Following MAEs environmental policies a Wildlife DNB Unit prepared a Proposal for the Regulation of Hunting and Local Wildlife Operations in Ecuador which will also be included in the reform proposal of TULSMA

description.narrative: PAs contribute effectively to the conservation of threatened wildlife

13 Increase in wildlife management effectiveness index
See notes in Table 19

comment.narrative: Average total score for 7 target PAs 3029 out of a possible 76
Average total score for 7 target PAs 5843 out of a possible 76

The overall average for the reporting period is 1357
The values for Year 1 are lower than those indicated in the project document is that the matrixes for year 0 were completed without the basic information needed to do so accurately Once the 1st year of the project was completed it was possible to calculate the value standards using more reliable data This is not a setback in terms of wildlife management but rather an adjustment to the reality of the current status of its management From the 2nd year of the project there will be a clear improvement in terms of the effectiveness of wildlife management
Average total score for 7 target PAs 5843 out of a possible 76

The overall average for the reporting period is 1357
The values for Year 1 are lower than those indicated in the project document is that the matrixes for year 0 were completed without the basic information needed to do so accurately Once the 1st year of the project was completed it was possible to calculate the value standards using more reliable data This is not a setback in terms of wildlife management but rather an adjustment to the reality of the current status of its management From the 2nd year of the project there will be a clear improvement in terms of the effectiveness of wildlife management

description.narrative:
15 Increases in capacities of PA staff in relation to the conservation and management of threatened wildlife
See notes in Table 19

comment.narrative: Personnel of three PAs 6 park guards in Pambilar 2 in Cofan Bermejo and 9 in El Ángel have specific capacities and knowledge related to wildlife management and conservation

Two additional technical personnel target PA trained and assigned specific wildlife functions
Provisions exist in MAE for the longterm institutionalization of these capacities

Between April and December 2014 through DNB MAE added 10 specialized technicians to the wildlife project From January 2015 five technicians remain three biologists and two wildlife veterinarians who support project management
The project began the process of training the MAE technical staff at headquarters and central provinces in different fields related to the management and conservation of wildlife Training topics have included i conflicts in people fauna management ii biological monitoring of wildlife at the landscape scale iii crimes against wildlife iv socio environmental conflict management v environmental management rights vi multiculturalism policy and vii a pilot program for environmental education for rangers in World Heritage Natural Areas of Ecuador PANE specifically focused on people wildlife conflict management and wildlife trafficking

Two additional technical personnel target PA trained and assigned specific wildlife functions
Provisions exist in MAE for the longterm institutionalization of these capacities

Between April and December 2014 through DNB MAE added 10 specialized technicians to the wildlife project From January 2015 five technicians remain three biologists and two wildlife veterinarians who support project management
The project began the process of training the MAE technical staff at headquarters and central provinces in different fields related to the management and conservation of wildlife Training topics have included i conflicts in people fauna management ii biological monitoring of wildlife at the landscape scale iii crimes against wildlife iv socio environmental conflict management v environmental management rights vi multiculturalism policy and vii a pilot program for environmental education for rangers in World Heritage Natural Areas of Ecuador PANE specifically focused on people wildlife conflict management and wildlife trafficking

description.narrative: 12 Increases in numbers of community plans and norms applied to wildlife management eg types and timing of offtake in target landscapes

comment.narrative: Six Kichwa communities Landscape 4 are applying community norms and management plans for the regulation of subsistence hunting covering 81523ha

17 communities covering ̴ 230000ha in 3 target landscapes applying community norms for wildlife management
Area estimate is based on average per community in landscape 4 at present to be confirmed at project start

Similarly using the result of the study of the socioeconomic diagnosis the identification process of these communities will signal the beginning of work on the implementation of policies and plans for the management of wildlife whose area is being defined in a participatory way and adapted to the realities of the communities selected
